awd_titl_txt: Self-Consistent Evolution of Extreme Mass Ratio Inspirals
awd_abstract_narration:
We will investigate extreme-mass-ratio inspirals (EMRIs) of compact objects in orbit around super-massive black holes that, due to emission of gravitational waves, eventually plunge into the super-massive black hole.  We will generalize existing methods based on the effective source approach from the scalar case to the more interesting (and demanding) gravitational case with the aim of being able to perform fully self-consistent evolutions of both the particle trajectory and the radiation field.  EMRIs are expected to be a major source of gravitational waves for future space-based gravitational wave detectors. The observation of such events can be used to test the black hole No-Hair Theorem by mapping out the black hole metric as the small compact object spirals in.  However, a successful test will require very accurate predictions of the full gravitational waveform with small phase errors over hundreds of thousands to millions of orbital periods. The slow orbital evolution is determined by the interaction of the particle with the perturbations produced by the particle itself, the so called self-force.  Though the radiative part of the self-force is solely responsible for the evolution of the orbital parameters resulting in amplitude and frequency evolution of the waveform, the conservative piece can still affect the phase.  Current approaches to calculating EMRI waveforms evolve the system as if it were going from one geodesic to the next.  The change of the orbital parameters is calculated from averages of fluxes or the self-force itself over several orbits.  The approximate methods have to be checked with fully self-consistent evolutions of both the orbit and gravitational perturbations. Using the effective source approach, such self-consistent evolutions are now within reach.

This project will leverage and integrate with several complementary NSF projects which focus on developing open-source codes and building research communities across many fields of science.  Within these communities, this project will broaden the existing infrastructure and computational methods and make them available not only to our group but to the broader self-force community.  A central part of this proposal is the training of a graduate student.  The student will be integrated into both the numerical relativity group at LSU and the international self-force community. PI Diener participates in two REU programs at LSU (one at the CCT, one in the physics department)
where undergraduates gain research experience in computational relativistic astrophysics using real production code via simple user interfaces developed in the Cactus group at the CCT.  In the coming years the REU research projects will be based on this project.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we have developed new numerical techniques for the
simulation of Extreme Mass Ratio Inspirals (EMRI's) consisting of a
small stellar mass compact object (neutron star or black hole) in orbit
around a super massive black hole in the center of a galaxy. Due to the
radiation of gravitational waves (detected for the first time in 2015 by
the NSF funded LIGO project), the small compact object will spiral in and
eventually merge with the large black hole.

Such systems are expected to be a very important source for gravitational
waves for the LISA mission scheduled to launch in the early 2030's by ESA. If,
at that time, we understand the physics behind the inspiral process to high
enough accuracy, we can use the detections of EMRI gravitational waves to
learn about the masses and spins of the objects, giving us important pieces of
information about how galaxies formed and evolved. 

Traditionally EMRI systems have been simulated using perturbation theory
where the small object is approximated as a point particle. This leads to
divergent fields at the location of the particle. Using the technique of
mode sum regularization, it is possible to subtract off the singular piece
of the divergent field and obtain the regular piece that is responsible for 
accelerating the small object causing it to spiral in and eventually fall
into the large black hole.

In this project we have instead developed a numerical code based on the
effective source technique, whereby the point particle is replaced by
an extended and regular source. This effective source is carefully constructed
so as to automatically and correctly subtract off the singular piece of the
divergent field at the particle location. The result is that the code never
"sees" any divergent field and, in this way, mode sum regularization
is avoided completely.

This is one if the reasons, the effective source approach lends itself
naturally to "self-consistent evolution", where the field produced by the
particle and the trajectory of the particle is evolved together in a
self-consistent manner.

Self-consistent evolution is important since, at any given time, the field at
the location of the particle depends not only on the current state of motion
of the particle, but also on the field emitted by the particle at earlier
times. This is because, in a black hole spacetime, fields can be reflected off
the spacetime curvature as well as propagate around the black hole and return
to the (now different) particle location at a later time.

Neglecting the fact that the orbit was evolving in the past is an 
approximation. It is most likely a very good approximation (at least for
large parts of the orbit) as the orbit will evolve slowly. Approximate
methods that neglects the prior evolution of the orbit are expected to
computationally much more efficient than self-consistent evolutions. However,
even with self-consistent evolutions covering only a fairly small part of the
complete inspiral it should be possible to use them to estimate the errors
made in the approximate evolutions.

Though we did not quite get to the point where the numerical code can perform
self-consistent evolutions long enough and with high enough accuracy that we
can use them to check the approximate methods, we made good progress and
expect to be able to resolve the remaining issues on a short timescale.
